titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis Papers
titlestmt.author: by Lewis Walpole Library Staff

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 01:00

did.abstract: The Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis Papers consists of correspondence, writings, financial records, and other papers documenting the personal and professional activities and interests of the American author, editor, and collector Wilmarth Lewis and his wife Annie Burr Lewis. At their home in Farmington, Connecticut, the Lewises created a world-renowned collection of eighteenth-century print, graphic, and manuscript material related to the English author, connoisseur, and collector Horace Walpole (1717-1797), and his circle. Lewis's papers are predominantly related to his work on Walpole, his involvement with organizations including Yale University, the Thacher School, Historic Deerfield, and the National Portrait Gallery, and the Lewises' social and intellectual lives in England, New England, and Washington, D.C.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This material is open for research.
Boxes 183-185: Restricted. For further information consult the director.
Boxes 343-355: Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the director.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into seven series: I. Correspondence, 1901-1979. II. Service and Affiliations, 1931-1979. III. Writings, 1915-1980. IV. Personal Papers, 1800-1980. V. Subject Files, 1903-1979. VI. Real Estate Records, 1926-1980. VII. Financial Records, 1926-1980.

bioghist.head: Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis (1895-1979)
bioghist.p: Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis was born in Alameda, California, on November 14, 1895, the son of Miranda Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis and Azro Nathaniel Lewis. He attended the Thacher School in Ojai, California, and Yale University (Class of 1918). He met Annie Burr Auchincloss (1902-1959) in Farmington, Connecticut, in 1923, and the couple were married in 1928. Together they spent three decades building a collection of books, prints, paintings, manuscripts, and decorative arts related to Horace Walpole, his circle, and his time, and formed a research library at their home in Farmington. Wilmarth Lewis died in Hartford on October 7, 1979; he left his home and collections to Yale University by bequest.

bioghist.head: Annie Burr Lewis (1902-1959)
bioghist.p: Annie Burr Auchincloss Lewis was born in Newport, Rhode Island, on July 22, 1902, the daughter of Emma Jennings Auchincloss and Hugh Dudley Auchincloss. She attended Miss Porter's School in Farmington, Connecticut, and married Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis (1895-1979) in New York in 1928. The Lewises resided in Farmington and at Hammersmith Farm in Newport. Annie Lewis died in Hartford, Connecticut, on May 9, 1959.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis Papers. The Lewis Walpole Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Prior to the Lewis Walpole Library's addition of climate-controlled collections storage in 2007, Wilmarth Lewis's papers were kept in several areas of his home in Farmington, though primarily in his library office and the secure "Muniment Room" that had been constructed in the basement of the Cowles House. Lewis always had secretarial help at home, but it is unclear who maintained his files during his lifetime, and what arranging or rearranging was done when the University took possession of the Cowles House and Lewis's collections in 1980.

During the summers of 1982-1984, students Cheryl Davis and Cheryl Paul organized the correspondence files by creating "general folders" and "individual folders." The general folders (i.e., Aa-Az) preceded files titled by individual names, all wives under their husbands' names, and a card file was created to record each correspondent. In 1984, the Yale University Librarian placed an access restriction on the correspondence until twenty-five years after Lewis's death due to the number of his correspondents--and those who were subjects in the correspondence--still being alive. The files were opened for access in 2004.

In 2007 Lewis's correspondence files were moved from the Muniment Room to the Library's new collections storage area, leaving behind in the Muniment Room most of the material that comprises Series II through VII of the papers. In 2016-2018, as part of the Cowles House renovation project, Lewis's papers were processed by archivist Sandra Markham and summer assistants Michelle Sigiel, Canaan Suitt, Alex Sowinski, and Annie MacPherson. The work accomplished included listing and rehousing the correspondence, preservation photocopying, and checking the names of all individually foldered correspondents against the Library of Congress authorities database to normalize names according to current standards. In general, little reorganization of the files was done, but the latter step resulted in many people, business firms, and institutions being moved within the alphabetical order. As examples, the folder formerly titled "Cholmondeley, Lady" is now filed under "Sassoon, Sybil, 1894-1989," the folder "Fleming, R. B." is now "R. B. Fleming & Co.," and "Chicago, University of" is now under "University of Chicago." Often, Lewis or his assistants filed institutional correspondence under the name of a single staff member Lewis had written to or had formed a relationship with, and only a few of these files were moved. Again, for example, all letters from or to anyone at the University of San Francisco and its Gleeson Library Associates group were filed under "Monihan, William J.," the school's rare book librarian; they are now under "University of San Francisco."

Readers should think creatively when searching the correspondence files and remember that Wilmarth Lewis's personal and professional lives often ran in one stream. With just a few exceptions, his extensive files were not closely examined or read through comprehensively for chronological arrangement or for the purpose of being reorganized to meet current archival standards. In particular within the world of museums and libraries, the folders under names of directors, curators, and librarians likely hold corporate communications sent from wherever the writer was working at the time, meaning that one man's folder might have letterhead from two or three different institutions if he had changed jobs over the years: Julian P. Boyd's folders hold letters written from the Historical Society of Pennsylvania, Princeton University Library, and the Thomas Jefferson Papers Editorial Project. Conversely, correspondence with Yale University Library remains as it had been filed under Yale and under the personal names of librarians such as James Babb, Bernhard Knollenberg, and Herman ("Fritz") Liebert, with whom Lewis built a relationship. In addition, there is extensive correspondence between Lewis and Yale, as well as the many other organizations with which he was closely affiliated, filed in Series II, so readers will need to consult both series.

Many of the personal letters in the collection dating from before Annie Lewis's death in 1959 were addressed to both of the Lewises, and there are often draft replies in the files written by Annie Lewis on the couple's behalf.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Associated material: Annie Burr Lewis and Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis Photographs (LWL MSS 22), The Lewis Walpole Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis Papers consists of correspondence, writings, financial records, and other papers documenting the personal and professional activities and interests of the American author, editor, and collector Wilmarth Lewis and his wife Annie Burr Lewis. At their home in Farmington, Connecticut, the Lewises created a world-renowned collection of eighteenth-century print, graphic, and manuscript material related to the English author, connoisseur, and collector Horace Walpole (1717-1797), and his circle. Most of Lewis's papers are related to his work on Walpole, his involvement with organizations including Yale University, the Thacher School, Historic Deerfield, and the National Portrait Gallery, and to the Lewises' social and intellectual lives in England, New England, and Washington, D.C.

Lewis's correspondence files comprise over half of the papers. Like Horace Walpole, Lewis built a network of colleagues and friends over his lifetime, making connections based on his interests and travels. His network was begun when he enrolled at the Thacher School in Ojai, California, and expanded greatly when he moved on to Yale University in 1914. The friends he made at Yale stayed with him for life as borne out through the correspondence files: many of the over 2,000 names listed are notable figures in twentieth-century culture as leaders in the arts, education, literature, government, business, and medicine, and a good subset of those were classmates in New Haven. To hundreds of others Lewis wrote looking for information or Walpole material, or advice on a Walpole matter, and scholars wrote to him for the same cause. He was loyal to many organizations, and the files document how he gave his time and expertise as a trustee and select committee member at his two schools, as well as to museums, libraries, and historical organizations stretching from Newport to Washington, and out to California.

As an author, Lewis was prolific, turning out dozens of essays, chapters, and books on Horace Walpole over a forty-year period, all while he was overseeing the final production of all but the last two volumes of the Yale Edition of Horace Walpole's Correspondence . A popular speaker, he regularly gave academic, commencement, after-dinner, and library lectures; the files document well over one hundred presentations, many of which were published afterward. Lewis was awarded eleven honorary degrees between 1937 and 1972, from universities in the United States, Ireland, England, and Australia, in addition to several medals for service and accomplishments from American universities, clubs, and the Royal Society of Arts. His eight scrapbooks and folders of clippings cover well the publicity he garnered for his honors earned, appearances made, and publications issued between 1932 and 1978. The collection ends with documentation of Wilmarth and Annie Lewis's homes in Farmington, Newport, and Washington, D.C., the guests who enjoyed their gracious hospitality, and the finances that underwrote their life and adventures together.

In a December 23, 1963, letter to his colleagues Julian P. Boyd and Catherine Drinker Bowen, serving with him on the National Portrait Gallery Commission, Lewis wrote, "Isn't it delightful being Doorkeepers to Posterity?" The Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis Papers present evidence of a remarkable man, a doorkeeper who led a life of collecting books, manuscripts, art, information, honors, and friends in service to eighteenth-century scholarship and to his chosen communities.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Printed material found within the collection was removed for separate cataloging and can be accessed by searching the library's online catalog.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Wilmarth Sheldon Lewis Papers is the physical property of the Lewis Walpole Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the W. S. Lewis Librarian/Executive Director.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into five subseries: General Correspondence, Chapman-Lewis-Whibley Correspondence, Lewis Family Correspondence, Responses to Publications, and Tributes and Condolences.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains Wilmarth Lewis's extensive collection of letters from and to more than two thousand colleagues, friends, and family members. The breadth and depth of the collection is what distinguishes it: Lewis's personal life and professional work were largely united and this fact is reflected in both the contents and the correspondents found here. Because he had secretarial help for most of his adult life, the files frequently hold two-way correspondence composed of incoming letters and the typed carbon copies of Lewis's replies. In other cases, letters were returned to the Lewis Walpole Library by their recipients, and those accessions and donors are noted at the folder level.

The first subseries, General Correspondence, spanning sixty-four linear feet and sixty-five years, is the bulk of the series. The letters are a mix of social and scholarly content, often within the same folder, and are international in scope though predominantly from friends and colleagues in the United States and the United Kingdom. Lewis's ongoing research on Horace Walpole is the theme of many letters, as is the building of his collection of books, manuscripts, prints, paintings, and objects related to Walpole and his circle. Over many years Lewis built—and mined—a great network of academics, authors, collectors, dealers, and librarians who helped him achieve his pursuits, and the correspondents come from the spectrum within those professions. Eminent faculty from Yale, Oxford, and Cambridge universities, prominent library and museum directors in England and America, renowned international antiquarian booksellers, and legendary editors and publishers appear throughout the files, and their names stand out in the folder list. Also present, however, are legions of English country house residents and their descendants, bibliographers, fact-checkers, and other less-recognized foot soldiers of history. Among that cohort is A. John Watson, a manuscript librarian at the British Museum who met Lewis in 1933, and continued to assist with his Walpole research for many years after his retirement from the museum in 1952. The two corresponded for forty-five years, and in 1983 Watson, at age 93, mailed to Farmington the letters he had received from Lewis; most had been hand-written so carbons were not present in the files, and the letters were added in with those from Watson to Lewis.

A special category of correspondents in the subseries is the staff of the Yale Edition of Horace Walpole's Correspondence Project (the records of which are described separately under the call number LWL MSS 23). The correspondence span dates after their names reveal the decades of dedicated service given to Lewis, their editor in chief, by the workers in "The Factory" at Yale's Sterling Memorial Library: Charles H. Bennett (1937-1957), Ralph S. Brown Jr. (1936-1976), Grover Cronin (1946-1960), Andrew G. Hoover (1936-1953), George L. Lam (1937-1979), Edwine M. Martz (1942-1979), Robert A. Smith (1949-1968), Warren Hunting Smith (1935-1979), and A. Dayle Wallace (1933-1973). Similarly, correspondence with members of the Advisory Board, including Edgar S. Furniss (1934-1967), Andrew Keogh (1931-1951), R. W. Ketton-Cremer (1931-1970), O. F. Morshead (1932-1977), L. B. Namier (1933-1971), Frederick A. Pottle (1927-1979), Chauncey Brewster Tinker (1923-1963), and Earl Waldegrave (1930-1979), reflect their dedication to the project, as well as to the editor. Likewise, the nine folders of correspondence between Lewis and his associate and co-author Allen T. Hazen show their mutual dedication to Horace Walpole between 1934 and 1977.

While the letters in the subseries are chiefly addressed to Wilmarth Lewis, many of a more personal nature were sent to the Lewises as a couple. Several sets of friends, including Dean and Alice Acheson, Stanhope and Nannie Bayne-Jones, Reg and Hope Coombe, Richard and Jo Kimball, Archibald and Ada MacLeish, Edgar and Constance Richardson, S. Dillon and Mary Ripley, and Arnold and Janetta Whitridge, are represented in the files, and there are occasional draft replies to them from Annie Burr Lewis. Other friends such as Leonard Bacon, brothers Moreau and William Adams Delano and their sister Susan Delano McKelvey, Felix Frankfurter, and Thornton Wilder and his sister Isabel wrote the Lewises, as did English friends Sydney and Marjorie Roberts, and Lucy Rosamond Bentley, who continued her correspondence with the Lewises for nearly thirty years after the death of her husband Richard in 1936. Also filed here are letters from Annie Lewis's family writing to Wilmarth Lewis after her death: members of the Auchincloss, Biltz, Jennings, Nash, Rutherfurd, and other families, as well as Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis; letters from Wilmarth Lewis's family are in their own subseries.

The files too contain fan mail received by Lewis, and none are more expressive than the letters from Marilynne K. Roach and Eric M. Simon. Both wrote introductory letters to Lewis, with Roach's first note opening "This is something in the nature of a fan-letter & thank-you note..." for introducing her, through his Mellon lecture series, to Horace Walpole. A children's book author and illustrator, Roach delighted Lewis each Christmas from 1970 to 1978 by sending him a Christmas card with an original watercolor drawing of Horace Walpole engaged in his daily activities; Lewis put all the cards on display in the library every December. Simon was a graphic designer, calligrapher, and painter self-styled as "Simon de Pittsfield" when he was in that Massachusetts city working for the Eaton Paper Company, or "St. Simon de Rego Park" when writing from his home in the Queens borough of New York City. Simon learned of Lewis on reading Geoffrey T. Hellman's two profiles, "The Steward of Strawberry Hill," in the August 1949 issues of The New Yorker , and immediately penned a letter of admiration in his curious eighteenth-century manner. After inviting himself to visit Lewis and his collection in Farmington, and arriving on June 23, 1950, Simon sent a decorated thank-you note/remembrance featuring portraits of Horace Walpole, Madame du Deffand, and himself, among others, with a rose painted especially for Mrs. Lewis.

The subseries Chapman-Lewis-Whibley Correspondence, Lewis Family Correspondence, Responses to Publications, and Tributes and Condolences, are special groups of letters that had been kept separate from the run of General Correspondence, and are further described at their subseries levels.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Susan Delano McKelvey (1883-1964), a botanist, was the sister of the Lewises' close friends William Adams Delano and Moreau Delano. Her folder includes a letter to her from Annie Lewis, thanking McKelvey for sending a nineteenth-century carved wooden eagle to the Lewises, with an attached photo showing the eagle mounted on an exterior wall of the Cowles House. The Lewises had long admired the eagle, a ship stern board, when they visited the New Jersey home of Moreau Delano, and it was a gift to them upon his death.

scopecontent.p: Correspondence in these four folders, and those in Box 152, primarily concerns publication of the Yale Edition of Horace Walpole's Correspondence .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Nuisance" holds letters Lewis received from people he considered to be just that. Accordingly, he marked some of their letters so and filed them in an eponymous folder. They are predominantly from writers who had read about Lewis in a magazine or had encountered one of his publications and were sending questions he generally felt didn't need to answer. Some contain a plea for money or help with Walpole genealogy (queries such as "I am in search of the ancestors of Caesar Walpole, my direct ancestor."). Several writers sought appraisals of old books, or offered for sale materials, both old and new; a man from Minneapolis asked in 1950 if Lewis would like to buy his recently acquired set of the Yale Edition of Walpole-Mann correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The subseries holds letters sent among three scholarly colleagues and friends, Wilmarth Lewis, R. W. Chapman (1881-1960), and Leonard Whibley (1862-1941). The Chapman-Lewis correspondence, amounting to more than 1,800 letters, forms the bulk of the material, and documents the close relationship that the men maintained for thirty years. They exchanged letters regularly, often several times a week, from 1929 through shortly before Chapman's death in 1960, and it was Chapman's wish that their letters be kept together in Lewis's library. In a 1944 note to his wife Katherine, Chapman wrote: "When I am gone I think Lefty might like to have his letters to me (which no one else could ever decipher); he has kept all of mine. Also the Chapman-Whibley correspondence. RWC 6.10.44." Katherine Chapman transferred the letters, including those between her husband and the Cambridge scholar Whibley, to Wilmarth Lewis in 1966.

R. W. Chapman was only half-correct in his legibility assessment: he also had handwriting quite difficult to decipher and the two often wrote almost in code, with some sentences just phrases with acronyms. In 1979 an effort was made by the library staff to transcribe (to the best of the typist's ability) the manuscript correspondence but the project faltered after the 1942 letters were completed. Chapman's letters are particularly vexing due to their calligraphy and complexity: during and after the war he wrote mostly on the verso of any available paper he could obtain, such as printers' proof sheets, galleys, ephemera, press announcements, and even incoming office correspondence. For instance, Chapman's October 10, 1946, letter was written on the verso of pages from an edited manuscript on Greek philosophy, and his January 20, 1952, letter appeared on the back of one to him from the calligrapher Aubrey West. In addition, many of Chapman's letters were composed over several days (they are dated internally throughout the narrative) and run to several pages, which he consecutively numbered in the upper right corner of each leaf. However, because he wrote on combinations of disparate papers—some literally scraps—and his writing is so difficult to read, many orphan leaves appear at the end of each year's folder.

Over the years, the content of their correspondence changed from scholarly research inquiries to a mix of personal and professional topics, always with the latest news of friends and colleagues—including those at Yale—and the Chapman's three sons and their families. Horace Walpole, books, Jane Austen, bibliography, and Lewis's acquisitions are the most consistent primary subjects, but an omnipresent theme was World War II. It was discussed with anticipation in many letters written between 1936 and 1940, and once the war started, the hardships began. Of the few (less than thirty) letters in the collection from Katherine Chapman, most focus on the family's gratitude for the packages of food, particularly the Virginia hams, that the Lewises had sent to them from various purveyors, as well as her requests for raisins, nuts (but not peanuts or coconut), and most especially sugar, butter, lemon juice, and dried onion flakes. The shipments continued after the war ended; one letter, dated January 28, 1953, was two typed pages only describing the fate of the Irish ham sent by the Lewises for Christmas.

Also in the correspondence are many third-party letters sent as enclosures from Chapman to Lewis, such as one of May 10, 1950, from author Elizabeth Jenkins (1905-2010), which describes her visit to Matson House in Gloucestershire and in which she drew a sketch of the windows that Horace Walpole had installed there. However, most of the letters are from scholars and librarians, and concern/confirm fine points related to bibliography and Walpole, or any of the many topics that the two men covered in their letters to each other.

Their mutual friend Leonard Whibley, a lecturer and fellow at his alma mater, Pembroke College, University of Cambridge, was co-editor of the Correspondence of Thomas Gray (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1935) and, like Chapman, an early member of the Walpole Correspondence Advisory Board. In their letters to each other, Chapman and Lewis wrote often of their friend, for whom they used an affectionate nickname, "D.M." (short for "Doddy Man") and his wife, the noted suffragette Henrietta Barwell (1878-1949) known as "Rhita." The Lewises would regularly visit both men's homes on their trips to England, and after Whibley died in November 1941, Lewis wrote to Chapman that he was the first member of the Walpole Edition advisory board that had ever been dropped from the Walpole edition's masthead.
Chapman retrieved Lewis's letters to Whibley from Rhita Whibley and they were returned to Lewis. Thus, filed in this subseries are the letters sent between Lewis and Chapman, Chapman and Whibley, and Lewis and Whibley.

scopecontent.p: The subseries contains only correspondence with Wilmarth Lewis's family members; correspondence with relatives of Annie Lewis in the Auchincloss, Jennings, and other families are filed in the first subseries, General Correspondence. Correspondence between Wilmarth and Annie Lewis is filed in the Annie Burr Lewis Papers (LWL MSS 21), Box 2, folders 10-15.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The niece of Wilmarth Lewis, Joan Maitland Lewis was the daughter Martha Mohun Maitland and her first husband; she was adopted by Azro Lewis Jr. after his marriage to Martha in 1937. Joan attended Mills College, graduated from Stanford University in 1953, and lived first in San Francisco and then in New York. She became the second wife of Robert Scofield Danforth (1926-1987) in 1974, and was a business partner with Wilmarth Lewis in inherited ranchland in California.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The correspondence here covers both personal and business affairs, as Joan reported news of her parents, her uncle Charles Lewis, and her own life and travels to her uncle Wilmarth, in addition to serving as the business and contracts manager for the ranch properties they owned jointly in California (which Joan often referred to as "our farming venture"). The actual business correspondence sent between the partners and their financial and legal advisors, as well as contracts, leases, and other documents, can be found in Series VII, Real Estate Records, Boxes 288-289.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Azro Nathaniel Lewis Jr. (1883-1957) was the third of Azro Lewis's five sons, and the first born to him and his second wife Miranda Sheldon Lewis. He graduated from Stanford University in 1906 and married Martha Mohun Maitland in 1937.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Lewis, Charles Lux and Minna Conger

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Charles Lux Lewis (1885-1969) was the fourth of Azro N. Lewis's five sons, and the second son born to him and his second wife Miranda Sheldon Lewis. Charles attended Stanford University but did not graduate. He married Minna Ethelind Conger in 1910 and settled in San Francisco; the couple had no children. Charles Lewis became the family's representative on the board of the Miranda Lux Foundation, created in 1953 after the close of Lux College, founded by his great-aunt Miranda Lux.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The earliest item (1893) is a letter from Charles to his brother George, sent to Wilmarth Lewis on June 18, 1965.

Conger (1883, Paw Paw); an invitation to the wedding their daughter Minna to Charles Lewis (1910, Alameda, California); and a photograph of Harriet Conger (1899).

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: George Welcome Lewis (1871-1951) was the second eldest of Wilmarth Lewis's two half-brothers. The son of Azro Lewis and his first wife Marie Stillman Lewis, George graduated from Amherst College in 1893, and settled in California. His Lewis family genealogical work began in 1894 and was continued after his death by his half-brother Charles. George and his wife Edythe (1881-1949) had no children.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes one letter (1885) to George Lewis from his maternal grandmother Harriet Wells Stillman (1819-1900), and one (1923) from George Lewis to Charles Lewis.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: George Lewis (1927- ) was the son of Ralph and Ruth Lewis; with his first wife Betty (-1972) he had two children, John and Joanne.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Martha Mohun Maitland Lewis (1900-1983) was the wife of Azro N. Lewis Jr. She and her daughter Joan maintained a close relationship with Wilmarth Lewis after the death of Azro in 1957, arranging visits in California and Connecticut, and exchanging holiday gifts.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Miranda Sheldon Lewis (1860-1922) was the second wife of Azro N. Lewis, and the mother of Azro, Charles, and Wilmarth Lewis.

They, and other early family letters, were transcribed by Ruth Day in the summer of 1980.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Miscellaneous Antiquities" was a series of fourteen small publications written or edited by Lewis between 1927 and 1940, in the spirit of (and meant to continue) the two "Miscellaneous Antiquities" issued by Horace Walpole at Strawberry Hill in 1772; in Lewis's case, they were produced and sent as a year-end gift to friends, family, colleagues, and libraries. While most were privately printed and distributed for Lewis by Edmund B. Thompson, at his Hawthorn House press in Windham, Connecticut, a few were published in conjunction with the Grolier Club, Oxford University Press, and Yale University Press.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

Also present are letters and notes he received from friends to whom Lewis had sent the memorial tribute he published and distributed, as well as cards that were attached to flowers and gifts the Lewises had received between late 1958 and early summer 1959. A staff member recorded in 1964 that there were "797 letters to Mr. Lewis expressing sympathy" in the files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series holds material related to organizations, including his two schools, Thacher and Yale, with which Wilmarth Lewis maintained close or extensive relationships through service as a trustee, advisory board or committee member, or other appointment. It does not include organizations in which he held only a membership. The files here contain correspondence, trustee board materials, reports, committee minutes and reports, institutional ephemera, and other documents issued by administrative units. Folders described as "board materials" hold minutes, reports, and some correspondence, and remain organized as they had been kept by Lewis in black spring-spine binders; the material was removed from binders in 2018, then foldered and boxed.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Farmington Plan was a cooperative acquisition plan undertaken by a group of major university and research libraries in the United States. The plan, drawn up in a meeting held at the Lewises' home in Farmington, was operative from 1948 until the end of 1972.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The National Portrait Gallery was authorized and founded by Congress in 1962 with the mission to acquire and display portraits of "men and women who have made significant contributions to the history, development, and culture of the people of the United States."

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Lewis attended the Thacher School from 1910 to 1914 in preparation for attending Yale. He maintained a close relationship with the school and its presidents throughout his life as a board member and financial supporter.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In 1972 Lewis began exploring with LeRoy Makepeace the possibility of publishing the extensive correspondence between Sherman Day Thacher (1861-1931) and Horace Dutton Taft (1861-1943), the founders and first headmasters of their respective private schools in California and Connecticut. The volume, The Taft-Thacher Letters , edited by W. G. Nicholson, was co-published by the schools in 1985.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lewis's photocopy of a 1971 paper on the Taft-Thacher correspondence by Taft student William H. Butterfield.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence and documents concerning the Trinity College Library and the Watkinson Library were kept in separate files for each library, but material for each was sometimes interfiled after 1952 when the Watkinson Library became a part of the Trinity College Library system. By charter the Watkinson Library maintains a distinct identity as a separate, non-circulating collection and continued to have a separate Board of Trustees during Lewis's lifetime; he was a trustee.

did.unittitle: United States. Department of State. Committee to Aid the National Library of Peru and the Geographical Society of Lima

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Following a disastrous fire in May 1943 that destroyed the National Library of Peru, the American Secretary of State appointed a national Committee to Aid the National Library of Peru and the Geographical Society of Lima, with Archibald MacLeish as chair. Lewis was not a member of the committee, but was one of several emissaries sent to Lima to advise on a new library building, the rebuilding of the collections, and the training of professional staff. While he was in Peru for ten days in August 1943, he visited university libraries, held meetings with government ministers, and attended social events.

did.unittitle: United States. Office of Strategic Services

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In October 1941 Lewis accepted an appointment to serve as the Chief of the Central Current Information Division in the Research and Analysis Branch of the Office of Strategic Services. The division served as a reference point for information about foreign and domestic places, and under Lewis's direction, data, documents, photographs, and publications were collected and organized for the use of OSS staff. Lewis resigned his position in November 1943.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The folders here contain little information about the division's work but for copies of the division's report style sheet and index guide, and three May 1943 photographs of a mobile kitchen in Stalingrad that are mounted in punch cards. Also present is the sign from the door to room 119, the entrance to the Central Information Division.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Lewis established a close relationship with Yale after his graduation, and devoted more than half of his life in service to the university. Most notable among his commitments was his term on the Yale Corporation, spanning from 1938 to 1964, and his service on three of its standing committees: Educational Policy, Honorary Degrees, and Library and Museums. Lewis also served on numerous other committees on campus, at the library and museums in particular.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Lewis was featured in a full-page advertisement in the Yale Alumni Magazine (January 1976) with his short essay, titled "Thoughts on $370 Million," about raising funds for the university library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lewis was involved in the reunions of his class, and usually hosted class members at a meal in Farmington. For the 1958 reunion, an exhibit of his books was mounted in Sterling Memorial Library; the exhibit signs and labels are filed here.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: An advisory committee of alumni and Yale Corporation members was appointed by Yale President A. Whitney Griswold to survey "the intellectual and spiritual welfare" of the university, its students, and its faculty; the chair was the Reverend Henry Sloane Coffin (Yale College Class of 1897).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The files hold correspondence and documents and material on William F. Buckley's controversial book God and Man at Yale (Chicago: Henry Regnery, 1951) and some earlier papers on the topic of loyalty oaths.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Under the auspices of the committee, a special convocation was held on October 19, 1946, "to mark the return of the University's collections to peacetime use" and to award honorary degrees to ten men. In addition, the celebration included special exhibitions mounted in Sterling Memorial Library, the Yale University Art Gallery, and the Peabody Museum, and the publication of Lewis's book The Yale Collections (New Haven: Yale University Press, 1946). Lewis's article on the convocation, published in the Yale Alumni Magazine , is filed in Series III, Box 257, folder 18.

scopecontent.p: In addition to general correspondence with Art Gallery staff, the files include correspondence, minutes, and other documents related to the Associates in Fine Arts at Yale University (1926-1958), its successor, the Yale University Art Gallery Associates (1958-1973), and its successor, the Governing Board of the Yale University Art Gallery (1973-); Lewis was a trustee of those organizations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The files hold studies and opinions on the overcrowding in the Yale Library book stacks, with solutions for storage of and access to the collections. A new classification "W" was one option which resulted in low-use volumes being removed from the shelves, reclassified, and filed in remote locations in the building.

scopecontent.p: Primarily general university ephemera and reports unrelated to Lewis's service.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series III is organized into three subseries: Books, Speeches and Lectures, and Other Writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series holds material related to Wilmarth Lewis's many publications as well as those he never published. Within the three subseries are autograph and typed manuscripts in draft and final versions, correspondence with publishers, editors, printers, and designers, galleys, proof pages, and some artwork for dust jackets and covers.

All of Lewis's writings are not represented here, and some that are present do not have complete documentation, but an effort was made to identify materials related to particular projects and file those together. Like many authors, particularly those who are regularly invited to give public presentations, Lewis repurposed topics and his writings on those topics—most especially the topic of Horace Walpole—and would change the title of the work. In addition, his final publication effort, "Fugitive Pieces" (Boxes 222-223), pulled together a number of his shorter writings which were retyped and edited.

The project with the most documentation is Lewis's 1967 autobiography One Man's Education (Boxes 225-231), but the series also holds minor writings ranging from short stories and essays from his college days to a 1941 editorial published in the New York Times, to The Tadpole, a play he co-wrote with his friend and Farmington neighbor Winchell Smith; it ran briefly in 1931 at theaters in Queens and Hartford.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in alphabetical order by title, including unpublished works.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Lewis wrote that "Fugitive Pieces" was meant to be a one-volume compilation of "fifty-two pieces I wrote from 1932 to 1978." They include short essays and academic papers, and speeches delivered by him at libraries, museums, clubs, conferences, memorial services, and various other gatherings. He worked on the manuscript in the last year of his life, arranging and editing earlier writings. He had submitted it to colleagues for criticism and to Yale University Press for publication estimates, but in 1980 the press declined to move forward with the project until after the final volumes of the Walpole correspondence series were issued.
Set one has original typescripts, edited.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The material in this subseries was kept together in a series of files grouped as "Speeches and Essays." Some venues and occasions were only identified by file title, such as "Freshmen 19 Dec. 1939" or "Moore, Fanny 14 Dec. 1965," with no other context; when possible, additional information was gleaned from Lewis's daybooks.

The files hold autograph notes and outlines, drafts and completed texts, correspondence, and publicity material such as invitations, tickets, press releases, and newspaper clippings. Some files also have offprints and other published texts that were subsequently issued. Dates given at the folder level are those of the events and do not reflect the span of material within the folder.
Also included here are transcripts of Lewis's appearance on the "Yale Reports" radio program (Box 247, Folder 18.)

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: With the exception of the first volume ("H.W."), all the notebooks had been transferred to Manuscripts and Archives at Sterling Memorial Library in 1979, and were returned to Lewis Walpole Library in 2011. They were accompanied by an envelope (now in Box 251, folder 2) inscribed by Lewis: "Not to be opened until after my death. / Wilmarth S Lewis." The envelope was over inscribed: "Found unsealed in WSL's desk drawer (with the notebooks) by D.B. Engley & Ruth Day while cleaning out his desk. 11/13/79."

The envelope held a card inscribed by Lewis: "14 Dec. 36 / These note-books are to be sealed without examination & are not to be opened until 14 Nov. 1995. They are to be given to Yale University for the benefit of the Institute of Human Relations, the directors of which at this time of this examination may decide what is to be done with them. / Wilmarth S. Lewis."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Filed here are notebooks Lewis filled with autograph writings meant for various purposes including research, draft texts and stories, and recording daily activities and thoughts, but they are not comprehensive on any score. Some functioned like commonplace books and contain clippings and quotations from works by other authors; some are written in from both ends to the middle (so were flipped to create a second opening page).
Titles in the folder list were taken from the covers of the volumes. Span dates were determined from the contents when possible.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: "Miscellaneous Antiquities" was a series of fourteen small publications written or edited by Lewis between 1927 and 1940, in the spirit of (and meant to continue) the two "Miscellaneous Antiquities" issued by Horace Walpole at Strawberry Hill in 1772; in Lewis's case, they were produced and sent as a year-end gift to friends, family, colleagues, and libraries. While most were privately printed and distributed for Lewis by Edmund B. Thompson at his Hawthorn House press in Windham, Connecticut, a few were published in conjunction with the Grolier Club, Oxford University Press, and Yale University Press.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Some of the files include typescripts, proof sheets, unbound signatures, and correspondence with printers; see also Edmund B. Thompson's file in Series I (Box 133, folder 14). Lewis's mailing lists are filed with the reader responses in Series I, Boxes 165-166.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series IV is organized into eight subseries: Academic Awards, Honors, and Associations; Address Books; Appointment Calendars; Family Papers; Legal Files; Scrapbooks and Clippings; Travel Files; and Other Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series holds a variety of material documenting Lewis's public and private lives, ranging from his eleven honorary degrees very publicly awarded by ten universities and the nine scrapbooks and twenty-four folders of clippings that cover those and other events, to his 1896 baptism certificate and World War II gasoline ration book. The Family Papers are primarily material collected by his brother Charles and forwarded to Farmington when his life was drawing to a close; included is Charles's genealogical research and some nineteenth-century family documents, as well as Wilmarth Lewis's copies of legal papers from family members' estates. Legal Files hold papers from the estate of Annie Burr Lewis and her mother Emma Brewster Auchincloss, the latter as it related to his inheritances. Travel Files contain material from several international trips, including two to Australia, that Lewis made between 1947 and 1972; the folders for the United States hold only transportation receipts and records for his travels from Farmington to Newport and New York, and some flights to California. The last subseries, Other Papers, contains Lewis's school and military papers, and miscellaneous documents such as passports, bibliographic notes, calling cards, bookplates, and, filed at the end, a collection of papers related to his death: obituaries, the memorial booklet from his service, and ephemera from public memorial services held in Farmington, New Haven, and London.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In addition to the diplomas or certificates, the files here may include related correspondence, tickets, citations, programs, and newspaper clippings; some of the material had once been in frames. Texts of speeches Lewis made are filed in Series III, and photographs of him during or after the ceremonies are filed in Series I of the Lewises' photograph collection (LWL MSS 22).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The subseries contains two sets of calendars used by Lewis to keep track of appointments. The first are Asprey and Smythson pocket diaries in which Lewis recorded brief details of his appointments, including names, times, and places, and some travel details such as plane departure and arrival times; he did not record thoughts or other notes in the books.

The second set are pictorial weekly desk calendars kept by Annie Lewis from 1940 until her death in 1959 and were continued after her death by Wilmarth Lewis or household staff members. Though Annie Lewis would occasionally note other events, the books primarily record the times, places, and names of companions for lunches and dinners, and in the later years, the times Lewis would or would not be eating at home. A particular favorite was The New England Calendar featuring photographs by Samuel Chamberlain, and there are several annual editions present here.

Lewis kept diaries during some of his trips; those are filed in Box 279 with his travel records. Other and occasional diary-like entries can be found in his Notebooks filed in Series III, Writings, Boxes 251-252.

Also included is an article on Annie Lewis's Red Cross service torn from the October 15, 1942, Washington Evening Star . The scrapbook is accompanied by a typed table of contents.

scopecontent.p: "Horace Walpole's Correspondence Edited by Mr. Wilmarth S. Lewis" was compiled by Annie Jennings to document the first volume of the Yale Walpole correspondence series. It includes the series prospectus, and other ephemera, typescript copies of Wyndham Ketton-Cremer's poem on the publication, newspaper clippings related to the volume, copies of an award notification letter from the American Institute of Graphic Arts, and typescript copies of C. B. Tinker's citation when Yale bestowed Lewis's honorary degree.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The "scrapbooks" here are three folders holding clippings, articles, and notes collected and arranged by Wilmarth Lewis's brother Charles. Notes within the material show that some was sent to Charles by both Wilmarth Lewis and their brother Azro.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Folder 1 (1934-1949) contains articles on Lewis and the Yale Walpole correspondence edition, Lewis's essays on collecting in the Atlantic (1945-1949), Geoffrey Hellmann's two profiles of Lewis in The New Yorker (1949). Folder 2 (1936, 1950-1951) contains reviews of Lewis's book Collector's Progress (1951) and typescripts of citations read when Lewis was awarded honorary degrees at Yale and the University of Rochester; also present is a set of six Samuel Chamberlain photographic postcard views of the Cowles House (1936). Volume 3 (1949, 1951) is devoted to reviews of Collector's Progress (1951), plus a color photograph of Lewis relaxing at Newport (1949).

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Following his November 1943 resignation from the United States Office of Strategic Services, Lewis went to Canada with Ray Atherton, who had recently become the first American ambassador to that country. Lewis then began to work with his colleagues at the Yale University Art Gallery, and museum directors in Ottawa, Montreal, and Toronto, to organize an exhibition of Canadian art to be shown in New Haven. The exhibition was never fully developed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials here are research papers on various aspects of Canadian history and culture, in addition to correspondence with museum directors in Canada and New Haven.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series VI is organized into four subseries: California, Connecticut, District of Columbia, and Rhode Island.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series holds the extant records for real estate owned by the Lewises. The papers range from legal documents such as deeds and rental agreements, to architectural and garden plans, and correspondence with architects and contractors. Also here are items that cover the social aspects of their homes including guest books, breakfast request cards, and letter paper.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Wilmarth Lewis co-owned the Colusa Ranch, consisting of 1217 acres of land on the East River five miles north of Colusa, California. He was a one-quarter owner with his brother Azro, and after Azro's death with his daughter Joan Lewis Danforth. The partners had both oil and gas leases on the property, as well as leases for cattle grazing. Other income sources were farm crops including safflower, rice, prunes, and a variety of beans.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The records here are primarily financial and legal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Lewises owned five houses in Farmington over the years, but lived in only one: the General Solomon Cowles house at 154 Main Street. Four of the five properties are neighboring homes along Main Street, and were either rented out or resold to new owners. Records for those properties appear in this series.

Records for the fifth property, the Hart-Deming house at 80 Main Street, which Annie Lewis deeded to Miss Porter's School, are filed in the Annie Burr Lewis Papers (LWL MSS 21), Series II, Personal Papers (Boxes 23, 53, and 54).

The properties were thoroughly researched by Mabel Hurlburt for her census of Farmington homes in a project underwritten by Annie Burr Lewis in the early 1950s. The resulting card file, with additional worksheets and photoographs, are held by the Farmington Public Library, and are accessible through the library's website (http://farmingtonlibraries.org/farmington-homes/).

did.unittitle: General Solomon Cowles house, 154 Main Street

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Wilmarth Lewis purchased the Cowles House in 1924, and following his 1928 marriage to Annie Burr Auchincloss, made several additions to the house to accommodate his growing collections.

The Cowles House is known for its fine carved woodwork and paneling in several rooms. The house was described in two articles by John Cornforth, "The Cowles-Lewis House, Farmington: the Home of Mr. Wilmarth S. Lewis," in Country Life , 163, no. 4216 (April 27, 1978): 1150-53, and 163, no. 4217 (May 4, 1978): 1230-33. The interior woodwork was covered in The White Pine Series of Architectural Monographs. A measured drawing of the fireplace wall in the Morning Room, by Yale University student Richard A. Kimball, is in the library's collection and can be located by searching in the online catalog.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Lewises kept guest books at their homes, into which their visitors signed their names and occasionally wrote comments.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Arthur Guiterman's A Book of Hospitalities and a Record of Guests (New York: Barse and Hopkins, 1910), OCLC 84668547 which was a gift to Wilmarth Lewis from Kate and Brewster Jennings, was used as the Cowles House guest register. In addition to their guests' signatures, the Lewises would later add to the pages photographs taken while the guests were in residence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Wilmarth Lewis began an alphabetical card index of visitors signed into the Book of Hospitalities (Box 291), to record the pages on which each guest's signature appeared. A gold-tooled leather-covered box, stamped with the Lewises's initials, was made by Sangorski and Sutcliffe to hold the cards. On January 10, 1980, Lewis's secretary Ruth Day filed a card at the front of the box stating "There have been 822 overnight guests from 1926-1979."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Likely typed by Ruth Day, the list accounts for the 822 guests at the Cowles House; in aggregate, she notes, overnight guests were accomodated for a total of 8 years, 3 months, and 5 days between 1926 and 1979.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Lewises had two homes in the Georgetown section of the city during the years Wilmarth Lewis worked at the Office of Strategic Services. The first was a house they rented at 3201 P Street, NW, before purchasing 2722-2726 N Street, NW. Photographs of the exteriors of the houses can be found in the Lewises' photograph collection (LWL MSS 22).

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: John Auchincloss (1810-1876) and Elizabeth Buck Auchincloss (1816-1902), the grandparents of Annie Lewis, purchased seaside property in Newport in 1852, and built a home there in 1857. When Hugh D. Auchincloss (1858-1913) and his wife Emma Jennings Auchincloss (1861-1942) inherited Hammersmith Farm, the house had been replaced by a large shingle-style home (built 1887-1888). Upon Emma's death, their children divided the property. Hugh Jr. (1897-1976) acquired the main house and Annie Lewis took a smaller gambrel-roof eighteenth-century house (the Jahleel Brenton farmhouse, 1720). Known as "The Castle," it was renovated by the Lewises and they spent their summers there.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Filed here is correspondence with Auchincloss family members, architects Gugler, Kimball and Husted, decorator Elisabeth Draper, and various contractors; a building permit was issued in February 1946 for renovations of the house. Also present is a letter from Providence architect John Hutchins Cady regarding the age of the Brenton house.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series VII is organized into six subseries: Bank Accounts, Investment Accounts, Yale University Accounts, Income Tax Records, Insurance Records, and Household Records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series holds financial records that document the retail and investment banking pursued by Wilmarth Lewis and, to an extent, by Annie Lewis, though the couple maintained separate checking and investment accounts throughout their thirty-year marriage. The check registers here cover accounts kept over a fifty-year period by Wilmarth Lewis at commercial banks in San Francisco, Hartford, Washington, as well as with Brown, Shipley & Co. in London. His Investment Accounts were overseen by banks in New York and Hartford, and by Auchincloss, Parker & Redpath, the New York firm of Lewis's brother-in-law Hugh D. Auchincloss. The Yale University Accounts subseries holds records for the funds set up by Annie Burr Lewis; because they were largely overseen (and expenditures were authorized) by Wilmarth Lewis for twenty years after her death, all extant records were filed in his papers. The final three subseries, Income Tax Records, Insurance Records, and Household Records, pertain to both Wilmarth and Annie Lewis; there is no similar material in her papers.

As the Lewises shared many of the expenses for keeping their homes in Farmington, Newport, and Washington, readers wishing a more complete financial picture of their lives should also consult the banking records in the Annie Burr Lewis Papers (LWL MSS 21), Boxes 29 through 46.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lewis kept checking accounts at several banks over his lifetime, and at some he maintained concurrently two types of checkbooks. Filed here are registers for both the office/desk format checks, which were often made out--generally typed--by a staff member, and second checkbook drawing from the same account in a smaller format to carry in a coat pocket or briefcase.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Hartford-Connecticut Trust Company was created in 1919 as a merger of the Connecticut Trust and Safe Deposit Company and the Hartford Trust Company. In 1954, it merged with Phoenix Bank to become Connecticut Bank and Trust Company.
